messages.subject: Re: [nihonto] Re: [nihontostudy] zzzzzz.  //  Higo Tsuba question.
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, T, Peter, peanut gallery, I d love if it was Hirata Hikozo, but I think the truth is closer to Peter s guess. What bugs me though is I studied Andy s
messages.messageBody:
Ron, T, Peter, peanut gallery,

I'd love if it was Hirata Hikozo, but I think the
truth is closer to Peter's guess. What bugs me though
is I studied Andy's Nakane a good bit in San Fran, as
I thought several times about buying it.
The iron quality on this one is better than the
Nakane, and the gold/gilver workmanship is better, but
the tsuba does not feel pre-1800s to me. This one came
from an antiques shop, and previously was in someone's
collection, as it had an old collection tag on it
identifying it as "dating from the 1600s" and other
tsuba terminology. Obviously I think the tag is wrong
on the age.
Nakane can't be the only one working like this
around that time, can he? It is not a Kamiyoshi guy-
or at least not to my knowledge- as their iron usually
feels softer, redder, and more refined in the several
I have handled and own.

So I'm still not sure what to make of it. I'll
probably sell it before the 2006 New York shinsa, but
don't like selling something before I've learned what
it has to teach.

Curran

--- Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:

> Hi Curran -
>
> Very nice tsuba! I really like the Hosokawa mon
> (9-stars?) that are part of
> its design. Noticing the very rounded punch marks
> around the nakago-ana made
> me think of Hirata Hikozo. I understand this form of
> punching is associated
> with him. Iron plate is rare to find with his work
> so I doubt this one could
> be called his work, but perhaps it is connected with
> him in some way. His
> illustrated tsuba are usually kinko which being a
> soft material, would show
> larger and more prominent "rounded" punchings around
> the nakago-ana than one
> would expect to see on an iron plate. Hikozo or not,
> the maker of your tsuba
> did indeed make a nice tsuba!
>
> Ron
> STL
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Curran Campbell" <neobliviscar@...>
> To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
> Cc: <nihonto@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Saturday, December 17, 2005 9:43 PM
> Subject: [nihonto] Re: [nihontostudy] zzzzzz. //
> Higo Tsuba question.
>
>
> > List & sleeping Peter K.,
> >
> > Yes it has been dead quiet. I haven't had much to
> ask,
> > nor much that I could help with. I have not heard
> from
> > Jim G in a while. Is he okay? Just super busy?
> >
> > ~~I do have a Higo tsuba question! I recently
> became
> > the caretaker of a decent Higo tsuba. Currently it
> > would be the only Higo tsuba I own and, alas, I
> have
> > no Higo Kinko Taikan! It has been the one of the
> few
> > book I've resisted (price) or missed getting for
> quite
> > some time.
> >
> > Photos are in the CURRAN folder of the group.
> > Link: http://tinyurl.com/9uucc
> >
> > Size is largish: 8.3cm x 7.65cm x .4 cm at its
> > thickest.
> > Gold and Silver, with extensive silver inlay.
> > Iron condition- very nice. Dense.
> > It is like the nice Nakane Andy has listed at:
> > http://www.nihonto.us/nakane%20tsuba.htm
> > but the silver chain block work is more involved,
> and
> > the mimi is raised around the plate, rather than
> being
> > part of the plate as in the Nakane. Goldwork and
> Mon
> > in both Gold and Silver. Iron seems a slight bit
> > different too.
> >
> > (1) How this one would be attributed within Higo?
> > (2) Approx Age?
> > (3) Fair Value? <*least important, but I don't
> have
> > a clue on this one, other than Andy's Nakane as a
> > ref.>.
> >
> > Thanks in advance to all replys. Hope everyone has
> a
> > good holiday.
> >
> > Curran
> >
> >
